introduction.title: Two Bodies Interacting with Gravitation
introduction.p:
Since gravitational force is a conservative force, the total energy of the two-body interacting via the gravitational force is conserved. The total energy E of the two-body system is given by the following.
E = K + U = \left(\dfrac{1}{2}m_1v_1^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}m_2v_2^2 \right) - G_N\dfrac{m_1m_2}{r}.
The kinetic energy part can also be written as sum of two parts, the kinetic energy of the center of mass and the kinetic energy of the motion with respect to the center of mass.
E = \left(\dfrac{1}{2}M V_\text{cm}^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}\mu v_\text{rel}^2 \right) - G_N\dfrac{m_1m_2}{r},
where
\amp V_\text{cm} = \text{ Speed of CM}, \amp v_\text{rel} = \text{ Speed of }m_1\text{ relative to }m_2, \amp M = m_1 + m_2, \amp \mu = \dfrac{m_1 m_2}{m_1 + m_2}.
Often we work in a coordinate system whose origin is fixed at the CM. In this system, V_\text{cm}=0. Then, we have only the relative position between the two particles to study.
E = \dfrac{1}{2}\mu v_\text{rel}^2 - G_N\dfrac{m_1m_2}{r}\ \ (\text{CM Frame})

subsection.title: (Calculus) Effective Potential Energy
subsection.p:
Since gravitational force is spherically symmetric, it makes sense to use sherical coordinates. For planar motion of planets around the Sun, we need only polar coordinates. In polar coordinates, the energy in the CM frame, which will have V_\text{cm}=0, is
E = \dfrac{1}{2}\mu v_r^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}\mu r^2 \omega^2 - G_N\dfrac{m_1m_2}{r},
where r is the relative distance between the particles, v_r radial speed, and \omega speed for the angular variable \theta of the polar coordinate in the plane of motion,
v_r = \dfrac{dr}{dt},\ \ \text{ and }\ \ \omega = \dfrac{d\theta}{dt}.
The angular part can be expressed in terms of conserved angular momentum,
l = \mu \omega r^2 \ \ \longrightarrow\ \ \omega = \dfrac{l}{\mu r^2}.
After expressing \omega in terms of l, we can group together non-radial-velocity terms.
E = \dfrac{1}{2}\mu v_r^2 + \left( \dfrac{1}{2} \dfrac{l^2}{\mu r^2} - G_N\dfrac{m_1m_2}{r} \right).
The quantity within parenthesis, ( \cdots ) is called effective potential energy, and denoted by U_\text{eff}. With
U_\text{eff} = \dfrac{1}{2} \dfrac{l^2}{\mu r^2} - G_N\dfrac{m_1m_2}{r},
we write energy more simply as
E = \dfrac{1}{2}\mu v_r^2 + U_\text{eff} \equiv K_r + U_\text{eff},
where K_r is kinetic energy in the radial motion only. When we write energy this way, the problem looks like the problem of one variable r, which can vary in range [0,\infty). Of course, in the real world, the planet is moving in a plane with both the radial coordinate and the angular coordinate. Equation helps us focus on the radial motion of reduced particle \mu alone.

subsection.title: Interpreting Effective Potential Energy
subsection.p:
How to use effective potential energy in Eq. and ? First of all, we note the K_r \ge 0 since \mu and square of speed are positive real numbers. Therefore
E - U_\text{eff} \ge 0, \text{ for all }r.
To explore U_\text{eff} further, let us use a simpler notation.
U_\text{eff} = \dfrac{1}{2} \dfrac{l^2}{\mu r^2} - G_N\dfrac{m_1m_2}{r} \Leftrightarrow \dfrac{\alpha}{r^2} - \dfrac{\beta}{r},
with
\alpha = \dfrac{l^2}{2 \mu},\ \ \beta = G_Nm_1m_2.
shows U_\text{eff}\text{ vs }r. The figure shows four distinct energy values of interest, E=0,\, E_1,\, E_2, and E_\text{min}=U_0. We can see the turning points represented by these energy values by solving E = U_\text{eff}, we will have the values of r for turning points in the motion in relative position, since at those values we will have K_r=0, i.e., v_\text{r}=0.
E r^2 + \beta r - \alpha = 0.
This equation has following solutions.
\amp r = \dfrac{\alpha}{\beta} \ \ (E=0), \amp r = \dfrac{1}{E} \left(-\beta + \sqrt{ \beta^2 + 4\alpha E } \right)\ \ (E \gt 0), \amp r = \dfrac{1}{|E|} \left(\beta \pm \sqrt{ \beta^2 - 4\alpha |E| } \right)\ \ (E \lt 0),
where we need to make sure that
\beta^2 \ge 4 \alpha |E|.
The solution for E=0 has one turning point with orbit having the shape of a parabola. The solution for E \gt 0 has also only one turning point with the orbit a hyperbola.

The two solutions in the case of E \lt 0 refers to the perihelion and aphelion of a planet in the planet/Sun system.
r_\text{min} \amp = \dfrac{1}{|E|} \left(\beta - \sqrt{ \beta^2 - 4\alpha|E| } \right)\ \ (E\lt 0,\ \ |E| \lt \beta^2/4\alpha) r_\text{max} \amp = \dfrac{1}{|E|} \left(\beta + \sqrt{ \beta^2 - 4\alpha|E| } \right)\ \ (E\lt 0,\ \ |E| \lt \beta^2/4\alpha)
The solutions of orbit equation for these conditions show that the orbit is ellipse with the smallest distance between the masses given by r_\text{min} and the largest distance r_\text{min} . When (E\lt 0,\ \ |E| = \beta/4\alpha), there is only one solution with
r_0 = \dfrac{2a}{\beta}\ \ (E\lt 0,\ \ |E| = \beta^2/4\alpha),
which is the radius of the circle of motion of the relative position.

figure.caption: Plot of effective potential energy versus radial distance r. Four energy levels of interest are indicated on the axis. They are E = 0,\ E_1,\ E_2, E_\text{min}. The system cannot have energy less than the minimum of U_\text{eff} since that would mean K_r\lt 0, which is impossible.
